text: From bottle in shaker. Pours pale yellow with 1-finger head and lively CO2. Fruity aroma is mixed with a bit of breadiness. Quite tasty and the Nelson Sauvin hops take this lager a cut above the rest. One of the best lagers in Oz imo.
Fruity nose but initial crisp malt on the tongue witha hoppy/bitter finish and aftertaste. Quite complex.

Pours pale straw with a nice floral aroma. The taste is something really different from what Ive experienced with other beers. The savion hops bring a white wine taste along with floral and fruity notes, quite nice! The only real let down for me was it is over carbonated for my liking. Quite fizzy... Overall, I would happily have it again.  ---Rated via Beer Buddy for Android

Pours a crystal clear pale straw gold with a good head of white foam. The aroma shows nice sauvin white grape, biscuity lager malt, a hint of general fruitiness. The taste is very clean, grainy, fruity hop. Its light on the feel, but flavour alludes to a higher than average ABV. Its crisp and refreshing, not too dry, nicely carbonated. Great lager.

Bottle. Pale. Weird large bubble thin head that does not last. Hazy straw color. Nice fruity floral aroma. Floral taste. Notes of lemon and passionfruit. Slightly tart. Decent. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Pours yellow, golden color with a minimal head. True: Smells like a fruity white wine. also picking up some floral notes. Sweet, bready taste with a smooth finish. Carbonation is a bit low. Surely not a ordinary lager, but not quite my style. Doest mean its not good.

UPDATED: OCT 10, 2014 Smells like a Savignon Blanc wine! A lovely, flavoursome lager - probably the best Australian lager Ive had. Slightly sweet, little bitterness, pale yellow, little head. Would benefit from a little more acid. A great showcase for the Nelson sauvin hops.
Bottle. Clear, golden, minimal head, white foam, medium bitterness, medium body, lively, & bitter finish.

Bottle. Light clear gold with quick-thinning head. Complex aromas of lemon, limestone, raw peach, honeydew melon and the florist just before you sneeze - jeez youd think youre quaffing some NZ suavignon blanc here - but I guess thats the idea. Clean no fuss pilsnerish malt carries it all and vibrant carbonation makes you think you swapped the sav blanc for champagne and a giggle. Someone has just mowed their lawn and you like it. Sweetish finish of lemon and hay. Bastard child of a lager Mum and errant wino Dad creates a confused but happy lovechild. Who you can drink.
From a bottle. Pours clear gold, tiny white head, lingering rich flavours and mild bitterness. Not bad at all.
Nice light fruity aroma. Clear golden colour with good head. A slightly bitter fruity flavor with apricot and nectarine finish.Light body with medium carbonation.
Tasted 6/6: Bottle: Clear, very pale, light head and lace. Clean light citrus lift.Good fruit and hop lift for a lager. Dry, not sour and low bitterness. Medium weight and length.
Light and Floral on the nose but has a robust body that is full of flavor! Pale on the pour, taste is a highlight. One of my favorite lagers.

Very pale, almost see through. But good head that keeps fresh. Got malt in aroma with fruity smell. Clean on front of tongue but crispness in the finish. Quite tangy for a lager. Good in short session. A bit high in alcohol. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
Nice beer. Classy bottle. Would buy again.............................................

Bottled 33 cl at 5th Element Bar & Cellar, south bank, Brisbane. On July 21, 2013.BB 16 OCT 2013.Hazy pale golden color, fluffy white head. Sweet, malty scent. Malty, sweet, bread taste. Bread, sweet, grainy aftertaste. Medium mouthfeel, medium bitterness.
Crisp, clean and a bit fruity. Nice mild bitter after tase. Could drink a lot of it but for the price
Never really understood the hype of this beer, however it is drinkable and has a little flavour to it.
Not bad.. pretty standard Australian lager IMO. Not that that is a bad thing.
Nothing wrong with the beer but really nothing to report on it either.  A well made straw clear lager.  Did the job of quenching the thirst.  Nothing off putting went down well.

very poor aromas disapointing for a lager. a hint of hay, 
clear, pale, appear.
medium sweetness, lightly bitter, salty, 
fizzy carbination.
an off-bitter finish
Clear gold pour with a thin white head. Aroma is mainly malt and tropical fruit. Taste - sweet, citrusy, with decent amount of malt and good lingering bitterness.

Pours a clear golden color the a decent head that fades to bits of lacing. Aroma of fruit, some malt sweetness and bit of grain. Taste is a  bit of citrus and some malt sweetness, grain and fruit. light bitterness and a clean finish. Light body, crisp smooth and refreshing. Nice balance. easy drinker, quite enjoyable. good for a few.
Bottle. Pours a really clear golden with a small white head. Caramel malts and sweet fruits in the nose - very subtle though. Taste is really clean. Says lager but its more of an ale. Not bad

24 Aug 2012, bottle. pale yellow, clear, occasional bubbles. nose is soft, grassy hops and crisp lager malt. thin body and very crisp. faint sweet malt notes but primarily lemon rind hops. crisp, clean, and light bitter finish. great for a lager.

A-- Poured a light straw color. Half inch head with good retention and very carbonated.

S-- Took a good minute or 2 for the beer to open up. Once it did I got a decent floral smell. Nothing real strong but is there. Also a bit sweet, like pineapple and mango sweetness. Once the beer opens up a bit it does go from floral to fruity.

T-- Not a lot really. Fairly neutral I thought. Got a floral taste in the end but not a whole lot else. A little bit of bitterness, or grassy taste from the hops but very neutral.

M-- Well carbonated and fairly lively. Much more hoppy than malty to me, even though it does have a little bit of biscut sweetness in it. Does get grassy in the end and it is a bit of a turn off to me. Would have rather have the sweetness than a bitter end to the beer. Or the other way around.

D-- Not my style, to be up front. Only one is sufficient. I really liked the sweetness in the smell and wish this was more fruit forward. Would be pretty good then. Summer beer only and decent drinkability for the summer. 5.6% is not that bad at all and do not really get much of the ABV in it
This is one of my favorite beers, a bit expensive for every day drinking, but well worth the money. To me it feels like an ale but the label tells me it is a lager.
This beer offers very little aroma but over-delivers on the flavour. The taste is more complex than any other lager Ive ever tasted
Pale straw colour. Citrus,grapefruit taste. Lots of flavour for a lager, maybe due to the sauvin hops.

Poured very clear pale amber with moderate white head that lasted a few minutes. Big aroma of sweet citrus that is great but has not much else. Taste of citrus nicely matched with bitter hopps with the hopps continuing to a very long bitter finish. Plenty of flavour here for a lager. Medium body with thin oily texture and soft carbonation. Overall a pleasant lager, but perhaps a touch too bitter.

Pale straw in colour with a lovely white head, Notes of grapefruit on the nose. The flavour is rather fruity and this beer grows on me the more I drink it. The beer has a lingering bitterness reminisent of a Kolsch

Pours a light yellow colour with a frothy white head. Aroma is fruity with some floral notes. Taste also fruits such as grapefruit and grape with some floral hops and yeast. Nice soft mouth feel. Long subtle bitter finish. Really surprising, liked this one a lot.

Brown bottle brought back from Australia by brother-in-law. Intringuing lager from Clave Valley more renown for its riesling than their beer. Best before 13 june 2012. Nice straw-wheat field colour with a white head. At first the smell is very nice, cat pee, some mango, New-Zealand unripe sauvignon grapes wine. I like this nose !!! The taste equal the nose with this ton of mango fruit, pineapple and this very distinctive Nelson Sauvin hops. Nice texture, good mouthfell. This beer is a regal. I would easy make this beer my back from work drink.

(Une dégustation offerte par rodenbach99.  Merci!)  Une robe jaune pâle.  Une petite tête blanche.  Un nez de malts pâles qui rencontre des houblons débordant de fleurs, dananas, de mangue et dagrumes doux.  Des saveurs bien goûteuses en fruits et en fleurs sucrées.  Un malt légèrement mielleux.  Une bouche de moyenne densité avec un pétillement normal et une texture huileuse.  Une finale amère sur des notes florales et fruitées.  Difficile à battre.
330 ml Bottle. Pours straw yellow, with small long lasting head. Floral and fruity citrus aroma - similar flavours - one of the most flavoursome lagers ive ever had - and very enjoyable.
bread, floral, dough, pale, clear, white foam, medium bitterness, medium body, oily feel, lively, bitter,

If this is truly a  lager than it is the finest I have ever had.  There are floral and citrus hops from the nose.  I havent had Sauvin hops before.  The beer is medium bitter and the hops bite has a funky, resiny note with some pine. There is a slight malt backing, but I dont feel as if this beer is as well balanced as the hops are very astringently powerful and are overtaking the rest.  This beer certainly has a high craft value and as a lager there is something very nice here.  At the same time, it is still in a category that I mostly avoid.  Cheers!

Gorgeous 330ml bottle. Excellent fruity/citrus aroma. Pale yellow, nothing really special for appearance. Dense tthin white head. Took me a full glass to work out my exact thoughts on this one. Somewhat tart and rather bitter. Long bitter finish. Overall, out of the 30 beers I have sampled this fortnight, in the top 2.

Almost as good as a lager can get, and certainly the best Australian beer I have been luck enough to find.  Hazy pale gold to green ... doesnt look like a lager but it looks promising.  Nose of grass, sure, but also of grapefruit and sweet and sour complexity ... doesnt smell like a lager, but promising.  Taste is more complex, more sweet, more grapefruit, more bitter than a lager, but really tasty.  So ... do we penalize the rating for deviationism, or reward them for tasty beer?  Tasty wins out.

Bottle @ Home
I have to say that I was very pleasantly surprised by this beer; I was expecting something rather terrible. Instead I got this rather enjoyable beer.It pours a pale gold with a white head; decent lacing. The aroma is fairly complex; dominated by fruit notes. The flavour is long lasting and brings out the hops. This beer must be rated excellent, especially when compared with the quality of lagers Australia normally produces.

UPDATED: NOV 12, 2011 Pours a pale straw colour with a medium dense white head. Lots of floral aromas with a dash of citrus notes in there. Tastes of a small citrus burst; lemon, orange, grapefruit. Finishes with dry floral hops. Decent enough beer. Much better than your average aussie lager

Bottle. Pours a sparkling clear very light straw with a dense white head. Head falls away reasonably quickly leaving a thin layer of foam and plenty of lacing. Huge tropical fruit aromas dominate. Mango, passionfruit and some wine characteristics. Decent bitter finish. Full chewy mouthfeel. Certainly not the usual aussie lager.
Bottle. Pours pale straw yellow, with small but attractive head. Floral and fruity sweet citrus aroma, and similar one the palate with hoppy finish, but very smooth with it. A decent lager.

From a 330ml bottle on 24/11/2010. Has a strong floral fruity aroma, with lots of passionfruit. Has more passionfruit in the flavour, some mild wine like characteristics, and a distinctive, long hop finish. Has an interesting, slightly oily texture. A very flavoursome lager.
light Nelson Sauvin hop aroma on the nose, with grapefruit and passionfruit tones . Sweet and fruity palate, light and well balanced.  A pleasure.

330ml bottle. Pours slightly hazy straw yellow with a small white head. Nose and taste is cereal/hay malts, pineapples, lychee and sweet oranges with a nice grassy/floral hop finish. Elegantly smooth mouthfeel with a medium body and well integrated flavours. I prefer more dry hop bitterness but this is still a classy lager that stands head and shoulders above the usual Aussie fare.

This is a very tasty lager. Has some good Nelson Sauvin hop aroma on the nose, with slight grapefruit and gooseberries. A little sweetness on the palate with crisp drinkablility that makes it all very well balanced. One of Australias best lagers for sure.

Almost a wine taste to this one dark ochre in colour. I dont get much of a lager taste from it a least not a golden draught style lager. This is a meaty beer with a lot of flavour but definitely better than many of the other ratings I see given to it at least I think so. Knappsteins are more renowned for their wines but this is a worthy drop to savour. 
A solid toffee sultana sort of taste that doesnt develop much of a head to it. Probably a drop youd only want a couple of bottles of at a time that would couple a good meal and nice bottle of wine.
UPDATED: JUN 28, 2010 fantastic lager, rather unique. very floral/fruity with a clean finish. getting easier to find in Sydney as it gets more popular

UPDATED: MAY 30, 2010 I think this is a fantastic lager. Beautiful passionfruit smell and flavour. Sweet, refreshing and crisp. Pretty light and thin on the palette but had a sharp amount of carbonation to it which makes it even more the enjoyable.
Bottle. Pale yellow with little head. Light floral hop aroma and sweet earthy taste. Light body, mild bitter finnish. Not a fan of this.
Lovely floral aroma, Orange in colour, small but decent head. Full of flavour, that also lingers. Very good lager. If you are a die hard ale drinking, you will enjoy this lager.
Bottle at Cloisters tasting ... Thanks to Barry for this one ... very pale yellow ... vanilla barnyard nose ... soft lemon ... fruity hop ... odd little strawberry ... really just not right

4-Nov-2006  - Very light floral hop and slight sweet aroma.  Clear flat look, lifeless head and suds lacing.  Big floral and light passionfruit hop flavour.  Bitter hop dry finish, but cloying hop aftertaste.  I guess more Pride of Ringwood.

Clear golden colour with moderat carbonation. Small white head that dissapears quite quickly. I was struck at how plesant and light the aroma was for a lager. Smells of hops and possibly a bit of fruit. Lightly sweet taste, with a sour after taste that sticks to the back of the mouth. This is a very plesant lager, one of the better ones I have hade.
Aroma of barnyard, earthy hops.  Flavor is of grassy hops.  Bitter finish, almost like an IPA.  Not a big fan.

UPDATED: FEB 9, 2010 330mL bottle.  Pours a clear pale gold with a thin head.  Aroma is floral, strongly resinous and has a mild sweet malty component.  Malty flavour with some subtle floral and fruity character from the hops, the balance is further towards sweetness than bitterness.  Light-medium bodied, medium carbonation, quite smooth on the palate with a mild bitter finish.  Really quite a good lager.

UPDATED: NOV 17, 2010 Bottle. Doesnt look anything special at all. Pale yellow, small white head. Big aroma of grapefruit, passionfruit, gooseberries and lychees. Taste is enormously fruity without much sweetness. High floral hop notes at the end. Just a  huge  surprise for an Australian lager. [3.7]Just slightly cloudy yellow with a medium white head. Fruit, grass and floral aroma. Slightly sweet with nicely-judged Kiwi hops - enough to make it tasty and aromatic, not so much as to make it a fruit punch. A hint of lager sourness. Creamy mouthfeel. Very good.

One of if not the best lager coming out of Australia. "Nelson sauvin hops is the bomb" - lgklotet

Appearance is not amazing but the Lychee, passionfruit, floral aromas on the nose make up for that instantly. Herbacious palate, slightly sweet. Well balanced Savvy, i mean beer
Cheers.
330ml bottle.  Strong grapefruit aroma.  Grapefruit taste.  Clear yellow liquid.  small head.  medium-light carbonation.  I like it!

Bottle. Was looking forward to this a lot and I cant say I was disappointed. Incredibly fresh aroma, full of passionfruit and black-currants... Nelson sauvin hops is the bomb! The flavour is bursting with fruitiness, mostly hop related. Theres a slight tang and a sweetness which really reminds me of a white wine. This together with the unique qualities of Nelson Sauvin really makes this beer remind me of a good New Zeeland Sauvignon Blanc.. And I completely adore it! Do give this beer a try if you can get it. However, be aware that this is a very delicate beer that wont fare well with either aging or travel..

World class!

Bottle 330ml. Interesting, if only it had more body! Aroma is good, it has grass, and also honey. Flavour is sweet to start, but there is nice balancing bitterness. It is thin on the palate though, and it doesnt look great, with a dirty yellow colour and a short-lasting head.

For hop heads like my self this is wonderful. Lovely golden hue with head that laces the glass. Nice sweetness with moderate bitterness. The biggest impression is the late punch of the Nelson Sauvin hops. Pricey but worth a few with dips during a summer sundowner.
Very well made. You can taste the class and pedigree. Very fruity and a bit sweet. Nice floral hops on the back end. Very good for what it is.

Bottle. Pours a very pale golden yellow with a little white head that leaves a bit of lace. Nose is interesting: lavender, lychee and caramel all stand out. Flavour is also fairly complex with the hops making their presence felt; hints of malt, citrus and chardonnay are noticeable. A little sweetness and a slightly long finish, combined with all the other elements, make this one of Australias more interesting and enjoyable lagers.
Bottle - pours a pale yellow with a crisp clean head.  Floral hop aroma. Grassy floral hop flavours. Dry finish.

330ml bottle.  Very pale straw colour with a tidy white head. Light and thin to look at with medium carbonation and an aroma of black muscat grapes with other fruity notes coming through. Tastes a whole lot better than it looks. Good body and balance with some sweet flavours coming through.
Had this one during my holiday in Australia april/may 2009. Clear golden colored brew. Floral aroma.Malty, grainy, floral hops, sweet aftertaste. Nice.

Pours a crisp, clear yellow. Pure white, short lived head. The aroma is amazing, think Marlborough Sauvignon Blanc. Lots of fresh cut grass, kiwi fruit and green grape. The taste is sweeter than the nose, but still very reminiscent of a good Sauv Blanc; ripe tropical fruit, a distinct grassiness and a dry, long finish. Very refreshing, very complex for a lager, and very delicious

Bottle. Pours with a large white head over a clear yellow-gold body. An IPA type aroma and flavour profile of passionfruit and berries changing to just a hint of malt sweetness in the finish. Pretty thin body. Nice.

Over a course of a few months this was easily my go-to beer for the need of an enjoyable, easy drinking brew and inexpensive as well for that matter. A really pleasant fruitiness from the Sauvin hops with passionfruit, lychee and berries dominating the nose. Theres no doubt the body is very thin, and perhaps Id like to see a touch more malt to knock it up a notch. But nonetheless it is a premium lager that tastes great and one Id be more than happy to drink again...and again.

Crystal clear pale gold pour. Inch-high persistent head.
Aroma is very "new-world": lychee, passionfruit, quite floral and grassy. Supported by sweet biscuity malt.
Similar flavours, with bready/biscuity malts, green/grassy hops and an assertive bitterness that combines with the malt to create an impressive lasting finish.
Great body and carbonation for the style.

330ml Bottle. Pours a very pale straw with medium long lasting white head and good lacing. Aroma is hops, with citrus, grapefruit passionfruit and floral . Flavour is crisp and is also  led by the citrus and floral hops. Moderately high carbonation, with thin (although pleasantly more than expected) body. Well rounded, delicious and very drinkable. Has restored my faith after losing hope in all Australian lagers.

Pours golden yellow with a substantial snow white coloured head. Aromas are excellent! Very distinct and unique, from the sauvin no doubt. Loads of citrus fruit and herbacious hops. Palate is quite light with minimal malt intereference. Really lets the hops dominate. More tropical and citrus fruit (passionfruit, lychee & grapefruit) with lager yeast bringing a clean, crisp profile. I often forget just how good this is!
Bottle  -Clear  yellow with thin white head.  Medium to high carbonation.  Malty and citrussy. A light bitterness. Crisp and refreshing.

bottled, big thanks to mullet for bringing this over with him. golden and lightly fizzy with a whipped egg white head, some kiwi fruit and passion fruit in the aroma, doughy malt, red berry, modest grapefruity bitterness, really well balanced and classy

Bottle. The sauvin hops are strong in the aroma - gooseberries and grapefruit. Malty palate, somewhat dominated by the sauvin hops. Grapefruit again, but not tart or sour. Would like to see mroe malt myself, to make it more beerish. Tastes like a winemakers beer - which I guess it is.
Light straw colour, very fruity/citrus aroma, flavour much of the same. Good hop presence, not much malt evident in this beer.   Good bitterness to round it our.  Very well balanced.  Sessionable!
What an excellent beer! Remarkable fruity nose and a clean palate that delivers a good solid bitterness. Is this the best lager in Australia ? It certainly must be one of them.
Bottle. Light straw colour. Poor head retention, but good lacing. Floral and subtle white wine aroma. Nice balance of malt and hops.

...bottle.  This was a pleasent surprise, and I was impressed.  Grea strong and citrusy and floral aroma, nice hop notes.  Color was a golden amber, with a small white head.  Body was medium, with decent carbonation. Flavors were slightly roasted, hoppy but not bitter, citrusy, passionfruit, and some malt.  Very unique for an Aussie brew, more like a fine wine.  Flavors were very complex, especially the sauvin hops, but still balanced.  Went down well, with a nice flavorful dry finish.  Expensive, but good, worth trying for sure.

Floral and hoppy, full of flavour and has its own character but is nothing unique. Very crisp, but not dry. Nevertheless, a mark above most others in its class. Its definately worth trying if you can find it.

Bottle. Poured slightly hazy very pale golden with very slight head. Little aroma but pleasant floral hops with some maltiness. The palate was surprising compared to the appearance and taste, it had some body and quite a bit of carbonation. The flavour is quite subtle, but pleasant. It is dominanted by the floral hops with some malty and caramel tastes initially and a fairly bitter finish. Overall its certainly drinkable but a little light in flavour.

Bottle.  This is a distinctive beer to say the least, at least in the Australian context.  Very dry, with floral nose and quite tart in the mouth.  I surprised some friends with this and it got mixed reviews.  Not sure its something Ill drink in large quantities, but a refreshing lager to the say the least.

Pours a very light blonde colour, very little lacing and a poor head.  Sour fruity smell, almost like a white wine.  Floral taste, very hoppy and vinous, with fruit notes of grape and lemon rind.  Dry bitter finish.  A unique brew but not one I especially enjoyed.
Malt hop aromas it has a wine balance some fruit flavours,grapefruit like,good on the palate.Dry finish still can,t get used to wine tasing beers but ths is a thirst quencher served chilled.

Reminded me of Moa in distinctiveness and its connection to the wine world. The nose is oaky, caramel and has almost a chardonny vinousness to it. The body is oddly more like a fine pilsner lagered in a cab sav wine barrell with fruit complexity. Smooth mouth. Very interesting and definetely not soon forgetable.  A definete must try.

Has an almost greenish hue, the way some sake does.  Very pale and hazy but no head.  Big grapefruit juice nose with grapes and peaches.  Hints at tartness.  Crazy vinous character...slightly sour with lots of grapefruit and peach.  This hop is cool shit, and it definitely grows on me over the course of the beer.  Very distinctive brew.

UPDATED: AUG 25, 2008 RE-RATE: Bottle (330ml). Poured clear gold with a good sized, fluffy, white head which was mostly lasting. Good zesty hop aroma with lemon citrus, passionfruit, mandarin, light notes of pineapple and some grainy malts. Flavor was a decent sweet, fruity hop bitterness with dry grainy malts, kiwifruit, lemon citrus, pineapple, apricots and a dry/grassy finish. Light to medium bodied with lively carbonation, a dry mouthfeel and a good finish.

UPDATED: NOV 3, 2007 Upon pouring the vibrant smell of summer fruits hits your nose. The pour produced little to no head but dont let this fool you. First tasting produced strong apple and tangerine flavours. A hint of lemon with a pleasant bitterness following through. This is one of the best australian brews I have tasted.

Bottle while dining at the Peppermint Bay gallery and restaurant in Tasmania. Clear golden yellow with a robust bubbly white head that leaves rings down the glass. This is bursting with delicious aromas of passionfruit, citrus, and melon. Clean pale malts intertwine with a complex set of fruit flavours: tangerine, passionfruit, rockmelon, as well as a pleasant herbal quality. Finish is crisp with a bitterness that is faintly resinous and peppery. Complex, yet endlessly drinkable, this is truly outstanding-- among the top 5 Aussie brews Ive yet tried (and Im over 200 at this point).
user_location: the land of bitumen, beef & beer, Alberta, CANADA

text: Citrus comes through immediately and finishes with a slightly malty/bitter after taste. Hopping is great, just the lack of head and lacing knocks it down for appearance. Very refreshing beer, would love to see their efforts at a Pils.

Brilliant packaging, pleasant Sauvin aroma upon opening the bottle. Clear, bright gold colour with small but lacy head. Wine-like flavours with loads of melon, berries and passionfruit. Only gripe I have is I just had to drink the whole 4-pack in one sitting!
Very clean, crisp lager with good hops levels.  Quality ingrediants, quality packaging, quality beer!

UPDATED: OCT 25, 2008 330 ml bottle - rich golden yellow colours. Head on the thinnish side but slides down the side of the glass with every mouthful. Lovely aroma of melon, freesias and tart citrus. This would have to be one of the most interesting & complex beers Ive tasted recently.  Sweet fruitness up front then a long lingering almost lemon pepper finish. Might have to track down a few of these to take back home with me.
Retasted 24/10/08 - just as good...!!!
UPDATED: JUN 11, 2014 Very fruity.  Citrus and other fruit tones - ? melon.  Medium body.  Light finish. Nice use of hops.

Tasted 07/05/2007. Slickly packaged 330ml bottle from Clare Valley, Sth Australia.  Cheers Jackie!
Pours a brigt yellow-gold with a billowing white head that tries to linger before fading. Lychees, honey, fruity flowers and lemony herbs on the nose .  Thorough malt profile, cleanly fermented, throws out just a little hop fruitiness but its not as overt as most NZ craft lagers. Weighty, sweet and clean. Creamy mouthfeel.  Then... wow... a long steely bitterness releases late herbal hop flavours remind me of rosemary, mint and aniseed. No wonder so many people are scared of Sauvin, this beer really showcases its intensity.  What at first seems like a Dortmunder Export gives way to an firmly bitter new world Pilsner. Ill be interested to see what else comes out of these guys.

Looking at the other comments the quality is obviously very variable. If you want to know what Nelson Sauvin hops taste like, this is the beer. Also has some Pacific Hallertau in there as I understand it. More a Pilsner style  - highly hopped, flavour and aroma.
Bottle at Chris_O bottlefest 2007.  Pale gold colour with thin white head.  Bit of eggy yeast.  Bit thin, some citrus.  Bad.

Mmmmm... fruity. Im generally terrible at picking the prominent players in a fruit salad affair such as this, but I think Ill have a stab at kiwi fruit. Plenty of body. Starts off a bit sweet, but finishes off solidly with some nice lasting bitterness.

A saggy old pale ale I sup upon typing this, brewed with those good time mates Willamette and Cascade, but it just doesnt cut right now against a new, more stylish and chic friend Id love to call my own. I downed a few bottles of this weeks ago - not satisfied at one - and I swear the flavour and bouquet still lingers strongly in my mind. It pours a pale-yellow gold, not exactly bright but it twinkles lustrously off the lights. Carbonation is fine, very fine, well lagered, well conditioned. Head develops well off the pour, a nice, level, thick pad of white that holds arms and never lets go, daubing well as the beer recedes to empty. Ooooh, exotic  is this aroma that wafts, sends me tizzy! All pear drops, grapefruit, rose petals, and a big whack of passionfruit, fresh-pulped. A little wheat softens it (I dont know if wheat was even used, but I got an inkling?). A wine maker, I swear there is even notes of Riesling in there that tickles on end, a little spice perhaps. All fruit in the mouth, lagering has not reduced this or stricken this of any fruity esteric delight. The palate is light, very creamy and sultry. Passionfruit is dominant again here as does some grapefruit and pine notes play edging at US hop-like characteristics. Quite juicy it oddly seems supple and dry mid-palate before heating up again as it drifts into darkness. Cracked pepper, rose petal bite makes use of the saliva glands, giving a good edge to it, the swallow all fruit, slightly sweet and mildly vinous with a good linger of pine adding more fuel to the furnace. This is just all class, stylish from bottle to glass. Beautifully balanced, bountifully aromatic and equally flavoursome, a truly nice drop. A surprise, so extra points for that!!!  I need me a few pounds of Sauvin. (33cL, The Beer Store Morley)

Bottled at Chris_O Fest March 2007.  A very, very pale straw coloured beer.  The aroma is poor and farty.  The taste is sweetish dull and has more sulphur charcteristics.  Pretty poor really but I bet its a premium priced product.

A Sim rate (Bottle at chris_os): Sweet, wheaty, fruity, citric aroma. Smells like fresh cut grass or more like the synthetic smell of the grass scented perfume that Gap makes. Tastes quite clean and fresh.

Finally have got around to trying this beer and I have to say its deserved of the hype.  Visually lacks excitement; just your standard light amber premium lager-like hue. Bouquet is choco-block full of passion fruit abd grassy herbal notes. As others have rightly observed very wine / sav blanc like (minus the sweaty notes sometimes found in Kiwi savvys).  Overt fruit notes drop off in the mouth but are more than adequartely replaced with floral fruits / hops and a firming, bitter finish.  Very different and really does push the fruit / floral aromas very well.

Bottle. An interesting lager, from a producer who is more famous for the wine they produce. This was crisp and refreshing, which i guess is what most people making lager are trying to achieve, however, this was a little different. This had some wonderful fruit punch sort of flavours. Some kiwifruit and goosberry in here, which instantly draws comparisons with NZ Sauvignon Blanc even though it is indeed a beer. This was fresh and fruity, and it just seems made for a hot summers day in Australia.

That rarest of beasts - a good free beer! Nelson Savin hops are the hop of the moment in the craftbrew world and this beer showcases them well. Premium lager is a class littered with dissappointing rubbish but this is not. Nice bright gold with NS hops to the fore in aroma and flavour with an interesting finish (citrus as others noted). Recommended.
An amazing lager. Without doubt the best I have ever tasted, so perfectly balanced with a gorgeous fruity bouquet of hops aromas.

Ok, my personal jury was out on this one for a long time.  Having now had it in the context of a couple over a good meal Im ready to rate it.  This is one of the best Aussie lagers Ive ever had, if not the best.  Strange melony, guava, grapefruit & grass notes on the nose.  Pours slightly green with a fluffy white head.  The flavour has loads more of that fruit - melon, grapefruit and underripe mandarin.  It presents a refreshing, long, dry and hoppy finish.  This is by no means a pedestrian lager, and it is by no means a bad one.

Chilled330ml bottle. Fruity nose, obvious parallels to a sav. blanc wine; plenty of passionfruit, pear, kiwifruit and citrus notes to entice, quite outstanding for a lager really. Pale gold body with seemingly minimal head and lace. Bit of a light grainy backbone of pale malt supporting the tropical fruit driven hop flavorus. A herbaceous note also makes its presence. Slightly creamy mouthfeel with a citrusy note of bitterness to finish. Definately a unique lager from my experience, well worth a try.
Malt hop aroma. Clear yellow colour with poor head and lacing. Malt sweet hop flavour. Flat palate.

UPDATED: MAY 7, 2007 Bottle -- Very clear, very yellow with a head that soon dies off. The aroma is distinctly floral and grapefruit. My immediate reaction once in my mouth was that its closer to a sparkling wine than a beer, but its beeriness soon comes through, with its bitter, quite lemony edge staying in the mouth for quite a while afterwards. A really interesting and unusual beer.

Just love it! Just come back from Tasmania where I was determined to search out all local brews. Stumbled across Enterprise lager (yes, I know its from South Australia) after trying yet another disappointing Tassie beer and thought well, this is just great! Now trying to buy it locally (Sydney) but cant get hold of any.
Very different.  Fizzy bubbles and a straw colouw.  Lots of passionfruit and a white wine hybrid.  Ver good.

UPDATED: JAN 8, 2007 Wow, its about time Australia produced a decent NZ-style lager, those Kiwi hops seem really well-suited to good, distinctive lagers, even though they can get a bit funky for my tastes. Very pale and very clear with pretty patchy head retention. Initial aroma is like LCPA if it were brewed in NZ - floral lychees and Nivea hand cream like LC with lemon pepper, kiwi fruit, an odd hint of treacle and some other raunchy NZ hop stuff. The aromas really strong actually... in both senses of the word. I dont particularly see the sauvignon blanc comparison. I suppose it has a bit of a white grape aroma, but sav blancs dont have that. Malt flavour is pretty limp, a touch sweet, thin and papery, lacking somewhat in both quality and quantity (esp. at the higher ABV) Id say. Its all drowned out in a mass of hop flavour anyway, which isnt as impressive as the aroma. Its kind of weedy and awkward, with a really awkward prickly, almost chemical note that I cant really describe. At normal hopping levels it probably wouldnt be an issue but the hop flavour is so obvious here that it gets quite rough. Its not bitter, in fact the finish is quite weak, but theres so much hop flavour that it more than balances the malt. Its weird though, when you start drinking it this beer seems amazing, but the more you delve into it the less fun it becomes. Perhaps its the disproportionately large hop flavour, or the lack of quality malt, but by the end of a glass you arent exactly tearing off to the fridge to grab another bottle, and the more I drink it the more obvious its flaws become. That said, this is a really impressive beer, and quite unique in the Australian scene, especially considering its wide distribution. Top marks for doing something interesting - hopefully theyll do some more quality lager styles too.RR: Drank the last couple of bottles I had from the bottle itself and there was something decidedly dodgy about it. I suspect it is actually the hops, but it gave the impression of something much worse. Weird.

UPDATED: JUN 12, 2007 Clear pale yellow with a fluffy white head that left minimal lacing. Aroma of passionfruit and some grainy malt, with some obvious parallels with a fruity white wine. The flavour is quite sweet to start, with a noticable hop bitterness coming through after swallowing. Fairly standard on the palate with an even carbonation, creamy texture and medium body. Quite a well constructed beverage, but it doesnt really inspire me to reach for another. Re-rate: Well, it certainly does vary a bit in quality. Half of the bottles Ive had have been good, and the other half very good. Its a shame the quality is temperamental, but when its on song its a lovely lager, somewhat like a bottom fermented LCPA. Fruity and creamy with a lip-smacking satisfaction. Bring on the next Knappstein!!

A really intriguing beer, but why would a winemaker turn his hand to making beer if it just going to taste like wine?? The aroma is so strongly similar to sauv blanc and the palate so light and sweet that it is difficult to believe that it doesnt contain wine, in fact, with its sharply sparkling character and lack of any lasting head, I am convinced it does! 
Its a bit too sweet to be truly refreshing but its fairly well made and an intertesting display of the nelson sauvin hop character none the less.

Poured from bottle. 
Found the first two sips to be quite metallic, I think this was aided by the carbonation which was a bit full on. The malt is the instant taste, but after this the grape taste is very overpowering. 
Nice for about half the bottle, however eventually I found the after taste similar to the non-alcoholic wines you can get from the supermarket...
A nice beer, but I would be tempted to almost say this is a wine cooler disguising itself in some respects. I would drink it again - but it wont be filling my shelves of my fridge as a regular session beer.

despite the nelson sauvin this is still a "premium lager" - a sweet grainy lager with aroma hops but not much bitterness. lovely floral hops in the aroma, with a bit of malt. the head fizzles away immediately which i think is a grave flaw. in the mouth, obviously quality malt used - pleasant honeyish malt flavour. quite full bodied for a lager. main impression is sweetness though, and not very complex. finishes dry with a bit of green high-alpha bitterness. alcohol evident. this is slick but just too sweet. the combination of sweetness and fruity tanginess puts me in mind of an old-style riesling (like one out of a cask that is). now give me a beer!

Bottle: Lots of good things are being said about this lager, so I was looking forward to seeing how it shaped up. I was also interested to see how the Nelson Sauvin hop presents as I had not tasted it before. Put simply, this is a lovely Pale Lager.Crystal clear gold (probably the clearest beer I have ever seen) with a very short-lived white head. It looks like white wine in the glass as not a trace of any head remains. In the nose... Well, my first reaction was "mmmmmmmmm". Initially this was just delightful; pears and passionfruit with golden grains. As it opened some fleshy grape notes emerged (hence the hop name I imagine), though after a few minutes it dulled a little. In the mouth a very nicely done fruity, herbal hop flavour dominates over a pleasant slightly sweet sticky-though-not-cloying resinous chord and some juicy malts. Very nice and harmonised very well indeed. The bitterness and carbonation are blanaced but sharp and work excellently I tohught. Fabulous example that good wine-making experience can produce excellent beer.

WOW !  
Big juicy fat fruit flavours with a well balanced long finish, but its not the finish that I like. Its the intial hit of passionfruit followed by what reminds me riesling grape juice in the middle. 
 Great session beer if you can afford it

I was as skeptical as the next man about this "premium lager" and was more then pleasantly suprised by the resulting beer. Big aroma of blackberry, gooseberry and a pleasant compound that I find easiest to describe as Lantana or Nettle. Fantastic mouthfeel and a long lingering bitterness.

As with many others the term premium lager and the winery source had me feeling very sceptical. Add to this the presentation and you can hear the wine drinkers voices waxing lyrically and condescendingly about how good it is to drink a proletariat bevvy once in a while. WRONG, WRONG WRONG. From the moment this is poured there is a feeling that this one has broken the mould. Very pale body and creamy head but the crispness and herbaceousness of the nose are readily present. The slightly higher ABV does seem to give this a degreee of oiliness in the glass which does not disappoint when savoured. The mouthfeel is thicker than the typical premium lager which, together with the muted carbonation, also lends itself to the comparison with a good dry white wine. This is a delightful beer from start to finish. For bulk sales this is marketed in a 16 pack, 4x4 rather than the common 6x4. Perhaps this is due to the price point which allows the carton to retail for around $53. Not cheap but this is not your typical swilling beer anyway. After all, it is a premium lager.
user_location: Potts Point, New South Wales, AUSTRALIA

text:
Is this a beer of a semi sauv blanc? I was a bit skeptical of a winery producing a beer, but whammo!! The end to end on this is brilliant, packaging is neat and classy and the pour was very smooth. I could liken the pour to the sound of a Mercedes door closing, you dont know why it is classy, it just is.
The aroma is huge on this, a range of floral notes and tropical fruits and this follows through to the palate finishes with a nice subtle bitterness.
For those that say that Beer isnt evolving, then this is proof that there is room for originality and raising the bar. I hope this stays in production since ive found my Summer beer.
Best Aussie Lager ever, end of story.

UPDATED: NOV 16, 2006 Nice to see an Australian brewer muscle in on the emerging fruity lager market that the Kiwis seemed to have cornered in this part of the world. Interesting that it took a winemaker to break this ground. This isnt quite up to the standard set by NZs Emersons Pilsner, but its good enough to be a future regular in my fridge. Its clear gold and poured with a tall shaving foam lather, good lace and good length. The Sauvin hop used here takes its name from sauvignon blanc and this is indeed remarkably wine-like. (Your views on sauvignon blanc will be a fair indicator as to how much youll enjoy this - Im a fan.) The aroma is very green and acidic, with strong gooseberry notes, passionfruit and lychee. This is full flavoured, with a big initial fruit explosion - passionfruit and lychee, again. Theres enough malt to carry through the mid-palate to a tart, quenching finish. Good bitterness. At 5.6% abv, this is a strong lager by local standards but theres no hint of alcohol in the flavour. The carbonation is very soft, verging on underdone but pretty much perfect for these winey flavours.   This isnt an everyday session lager any more than sauvignon blanc is an everyday wine. This will pair well with food  - a lemon and thyme risotto or anything with subtle citric flavours, for example. The packaging and marketing mark this down as that most ghastly of creations, a "premium" beer. But unlike, say Moorilla Estates pale ale, this is good enough to get away with it. Its not often I finish a new lager and regret not having placed another couple in the fridge. Big thumbs up. (330ml bottle from Liquor on Parade, Kingsford. Best before July 5 07)

This is a great lager.
classic sharp straw appearance, average head retention, amazing fruity, and floral, vineous aroma, which translates into a unusual vinous edge to the flavour, apparently due to use of new hop variety. The best commercial lager I have had in years.
Nice malty aroma with hint of passionfruit. As warms up hint of grass hops. Bright yellow in colour with small white head. Good balance of hop and malt but dry finish.

Clear bright golden body with a decent white head. Sweet fruity aroma, notes of  passionfruit and melon. Body is a bit thin after what the nose promised, citrus and resin with an enjoyable bitter finish.

Bottled from Purvis Cellars. Standard yellow colour with minimal head. Stong fruity and floral aroma just as per the description. Very, very bitter almost as much as an APA but without the grapefruit taste. Heaps of hops have obviously gone into this brew. The huge flavour really works well. $4.45 per 330ml bottle and worth every cent.

Tropical fruit flavours with citrus notes that leap out. Palate finishes long and cleanly. A bavarian style lager by Paul Smith, out of the new Knappstein microbrewery, definately someone ill be keeping an eye on. Excellent drop!
